Social smile - 1 to 2 months

 

Pincer grasp - 9 to 12 months

 

Walks 1-2 steps - 12 to 15 months

 

Educational Objective:

 

Memorize the typical age ranges for key developmental milestones in infants, such as transferring objects, social smiling, pincer grasp, and walking.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart disease has equal saturation in all the chambers of the heart? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

 

  • TAPVC is a congenital heart defect where oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins does not reach the left atrium but instead reaches the right atrium, which contains deoxygenated blood.
  • The pulmonary veins drain into the superior vena cava or the inferior vena cava, or both, causing a total mixing lesion. This mixing lesion leads to the oxygenated blood passing to the right ventricle and pulmonary artery, and to the left atrium through the atrial septal defect or the patent foramen ovale, and then to the left ventricle.
  • The left atrium receives blood only from this shunt and not from the pulmonary veins, as all of them are draining to the right atrium.
  • This shunt causes equal saturation of oxygenated blood in all four chambers of the heart since the blood from the right atrium reaches all other chambers.  TAPVC can present with cyanosis, respiratory distress, tachypnea, tachycardia, and poor feeding in neonates.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by echocardiography, which shows the abnormal venous return of the pulmonary veins.
  • Treatment requires surgical repair to establish normal pulmonary venous return and improve oxygen saturation. The surgery should be performed as soon as possible to prevent irreversible pulmonary hypertension and cardiac failure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetralogy of Fallot: Tetralogy of fallot will not have some saturation in all chambers. Remember the x ray finding is boot shape heart

 

Option C. Tricuspid atresia: Tricuspid atresia will have decrease blood flow going from right atrium to right ventricle. So there will be difference in saturation in chambers.

 

Option D. Transposition of great arteries: In this condition the pulmonary artery is attached to the left ventricle & aorta is attached to the right ventricle which leads to parallel circulation. There will be saturation difference.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Circulation (TAPVC), there is equal oxygen saturation in all chambers of the heart due to the complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood in the right atrium.

questions.text: Hormone Replacement Therapy is not indicated for: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CAD Prophylaxis

 

Explanation:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) is not recommended for the prophylaxis of coronary artery disease (CAD). Although there was some belief in the past that HRT might provide cardiovascular benefits, extensive research has shown that HRT does not prevent CAD and may, in fact, increase the risk of certain cardiovascular events in some women.

 

HRT is primarily indicated for the management of symptoms associated with menopause and for certain therapeutic and prophylactic uses:

 

Therapeutic Indications:

 

  • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents
  • Premature ovarian failure
  • Hot flashes (vasomotor symptoms)
  • Vaginal dryness

 

Prophylactic Indications:

 

  • Prevention of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women

 

Risks of HRT:

 

  • Increased risk of endometrial cancer (particularly with unopposed estrogen in women with an intact uterus)
  • Increased risk of breast cancer
  • Increased risk of ovarian cancer
  • Increased risk of thromboembolism
  • Possible adverse effects on lipid profiles
  • Increased risk of gallstones and liver dysfunction

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hot flashes: HRT is widely used to manage hot flashes and other vasomotor symptoms associated with menopause. It is one of the most effective treatments for these symptoms.

 

Option C. Osteoporosis: HRT is used prophylactically to prevent osteoporosis in postmenopausal women by maintaining bone density and reducing the risk of fractures.

 

Option D. Premature menopause: Women experiencing premature menopause or premature ovarian failure can benefit from HRT to manage symptoms and reduce the long-term risks associated with early loss of estrogen, including osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) is not indicated for the prophylaxis of coronary artery disease (CAD).

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 61,62

questions.text: A nurse removes her latex gloves contaminated with blood and bodily fluids after a procedure. According to biomedical waste management guidelines, into which colored bag should she place the used gloves for disposal? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Red

 

  • Latex gloves contaminated with blood and other bodily fluids are considered contaminated waste (recyclable) and should be disposed of in red-colored bags or containers.
  • This category includes items like tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles), and gloves.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the condition seen in the image? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pterygium

 

  • The given image shows Pterygium which is a triangular/wing shaped encroachment of conjunctiva on the cornea.

 

PTERYGIUM:

 

  • A pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular subepithelial ingrowth of degenerative bulbar conjunctival tissue over the limbus onto the cornea.
  • Typically develops in patients who have been living in sunny countries and may represent a response to UV exposure and chronic surface dryness.
  • Familial.
  • Histologically similar to a pinguecula: shows elastotic degenerative changes in vascularized subepithelial stromal collagen.
  • Encroaches onto the cornea, invading the Bowman layer.
  • Clinical features 
    • Mostly asymptomatic.
    • Irritation and grittiness are caused by a dellen localized drying effect.
    • Lesions may interfere with vision by obscuring the visual axis or inducing astigmatism.
    • Cosmesis may be a significant problem.
    • Extensive lesions (if recurrent) may have subconjunctival fibrosis extending to the fornices causing restricted ocular excursion.
    • Made up of three parts: a cap (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge), a head and a body.
    • Linear epithelial iron deposition (Stocker line): seen in the corneal epithelium anterior to the head of the pterygium.
    • Fuchs islets are small discrete whitish flecks consisting of clusters of pterygial epithelial cells often present at the advancing edge.
    • Aggressive growth or an atypical appearance should prompt excision biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinguecula: Unlike pterygium, a pinguecula does not grow across the cornea but remains confined to the conjunctiva. It appears as a yellowish, slightly raised lesion on the conjunctiva near the cornea, usually on the nasal side.

 

Option C. Chemical Burn: This would typically present with more diffuse redness, possible corneal haze, and severe discomfort. The eye would look more acutely inflamed and could show signs of limbal ischemia or whitening.

 

Option D. Thermal Burn: Similar to chemical burns, a thermal burn would involve more diffuse damage and typically present signs of acute injury, such as eyelid burns, charred lashes, or more extensive tissue damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium is identifiable by its characteristic growth from the conjunctiva onto the cornea, often due to prolonged UV exposure, appearing as a wing-shaped film on the eye.

questions.text: A middle aged male presented with features of neck swelling, exophthalmos, sweating, tachycardia and tremors. Which of the following is the likely associated finding in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti thyroid receptor antibody

 

This patient presents with classic signs of hyperthyroidism, including:

 

  • Neck swelling Goiter
  • Exophthalmos Bulging eyes
  • Sweating, tachycardia, tremors Signs of increased sympathetic activity

 

The given history and the picture of the patient suggest a diagnosis of hyperthyroidism the commonest cause of which is Gravess disease.

 

The most common antibody subtype, known as thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI), is observed in approximately 90% of patients. TSI binds to the TSH receptor and mimics its actions, stimulating adenyl cyclase and increasing the release of thyroid hormones.

 

  • Anti thyroid stimulating antibody cannot be the answer as such an antibody
  • Since TSI stimulates the gland for the formation of thyroid hormones. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-TPO antibody: Associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

Option B. Anti-thyroglobulin antibody: Also associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

Option C. Anti-thyroid stimulating antibody: Incorrect terminology for TSI, which is already covered under anti-thyroid receptor antibody.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graves' disease is associated with anti-thyroid receptor antibodies (TSI), which stimulate the thyroid gland to produce excess thyroid hormones, leading to hyperthyroidism. The presence of neck swelling, exophthalmos, and other hyperthyroid symptoms strongly suggests this diagnosis.

 

Graves Disease Key Features:

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 1081

questions.text: Which extracellular cell adhesion is disrupted by Vibrio cholerae? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occludens

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae disrupts occludens, specifically targeting tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, which impairs their barrier function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrin: Primarily involved in cell-extracellular matrix adhesion, not typically disrupted by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option B. Cadherin: Important for cell-cell adhesion in adherens junctions, not the main target of Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect, as occludens are indeed affected by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio cholerae specifically targets occludens, which are crucial components of tight junctions, thereby compromising intestinal epithelial barrier functions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of chronic sinusitis presents to the clinic with complaints of nasal congestion, anosmia (loss of smell), and recurrent episodes of facial pressure. She reports that these symptoms have been persistent for the past several months, despite using over-the-counter nasal sprays and decongestants. On physical examination, nasal endoscopy reveals bilateral pale, edematous masses in the nasal cavity consistent with nasal polyps. She denies any history of allergies or asthma as a child but notes that she developed wheezing and shortness of breath in her late 30s, which has been managed with inhalers. Nasal polyps are commonly associated with which conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Intrinsic (non-allergic) asthma

 

Explanation:

 

Intrinsic asthma, also known as non-allergic asthma, is commonly associated with nasal polyps. This form of asthma typically develops in adulthood and is not linked to an atopic or allergic component. The pathophysiology involves a non-IgE-mediated mechanism with chronic inflammation driven by eosinophils and neutrophils. Nasal polyps in intrinsic asthma arise from persistent inflammation of the nasal passages and sinuses, contributing to the common symptoms of nasal obstruction and anosmia. This condition contrasts with allergic asthma, which usually involves IgE-mediated hypersensitivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic rhinitis: While allergic rhinitis is a common cause of nasal symptoms, it is more frequently associated with allergic asthma rather than intrinsic asthma. Nasal polyps can occur but are less characteristic in this context.

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis: Nasal polyps are seen in patients with cystic fibrosis due to chronic sinus infections and inflammation. However, cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder and not typically linked to adult-onset asthma.

 

Option D. Wegener's granulomatosis: Also known as granulomatosis with polyangiitis, this condition can cause nasal symptoms, but it is characterized by necrotizing vasculitis, granuloma formation, and is not commonly associated with nasal polyps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal polyps are commonly associated with intrinsic (non-allergic) asthma, chronic sinusitis, and conditions involving persistent airway inflammation, such as cystic fibrosis. Unlike allergic asthma, intrinsic asthma does not involve IgE-mediated pathways and often develops in adulthood, with nasal polyps being a frequent comorbidity due to chronic inflammation of the nasal passages. Understanding the associations between nasal polyps and respiratory conditions helps guide diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Cells don't lyse in hypotonic solution

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spherical cells may be seen

 

G6PD deficiency can have spherical red cells.

 

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD. is an enzyme that helps in the synthesis of NADPH. NADPH helps in keeping glutathione in a reduced state (GSH). This reduced glutathione acts as a defense against oxidative damage.

 

In G6PD deficiency, RBCs are exposed to oxidants. These cross-linking of the reactive sulfhydryl groups in the globin chain of hemoglobin. These are then deposited as inclusions in RBC membranes as Heinz bodies. When these RBCs pass-through spleen, macrophages pluck out these membrane inclusions. The remaining cells are seen as bite cells. Less severely damaged cells lose a part of their membrane, forming spherocytes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spectrin: Spectrin is a part of the RBC membrane skeleton. It is commonly defective in hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Cells don't lyse in hypotonic solution: Normal biconcave RBCs have a bit of an 'extra space'. They can accommodate a little fluid when exposed to a hypotonic solution. But spherocytes have already lost a part of its membrane, so are relatively full. Hence if they are placed in a hypotonic solution, they absorb more fluid and result in lysis of RBCs. This forms the basis of testing spherocytes in Hereditary spherocytosis or G6PD and is known as osmotic fragility testing.

 

Option D. Cells lyse in hypertonic solution: Placing RBCs in a hypertonic solution causes them to lose water and shrink, but significant hemolysis does not typically occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

What is G6PD Deficiency?

 

  • A genetic enzymopathy, inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.
  • G6PD is an enzyme in the pentose phosphate pathway that generates NADPH, which helps maintain reduced glutathione (GSH).
  • GSH protects red blood cells (RBCs) from oxidative damage.

 

What Happens in G6PD Deficiency?

 

  • Without enough G6PD, RBCs are vulnerable to oxidative stress, such as:
    • Infections
    • Drugs (e.g., sulfa drugs, antimalarials)
    • Fava beans

 

Key peripheral smear findings:

 

  • Bite cells
  • Heinz bodies

 

In glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, red blood cells become spherical (spherocytes) due to oxidative damage and the removal of damaged membrane by the spleen, leading to hemolytic anemia.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1198-1199

choices.text: A, B, C, D
A, C, D

questions.text:
Which of the following can be used to calculate the cardiac output? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. ECHO.
  2. Ventilation-perfusion scan.
  3. Thermodilution.
  4. Fick's principle
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A, C, D

 

Fick principle, thermodilution, and ECHO can be used to measure cardiac output.

 

Cardiac output is the amount of blood pumped by the heart into the aorta every minute. The average cardiac output is 5L/min and can be measured by various indirect methods.

 

Option A. Doppler echocardiography is a method for detecting the direction and velocity of moving blood within the heart. This is also a popular method to measure cardiac output.

 

Option C. Thermodilution method - a known volume of cold sterile solution is injected into the right atrium via inferior vena cava by using a catheter. Cardiac output is measured by determining the resultant change in the blood temperature in pulmonary artery. For this purpose, two thermistors (temperature transducers) are used. One of them is placed in the inferior vena cava and the second one is placed in pulmonary artery. A pulmonary artery catheter is used to place the thermistors in their positions.

 

Option D. The Fick principle, as applied to cardiac output, relies on the recognition that the total uptake of oxygen by the peripheral tissues is equal to the product of the blood flow to the peripheral tissues and the arterial-venous oxygen concentration difference.

Formula:

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Indirect methods used to measure cardiac output:

 

  1. By using Fick principle
  2. Indicator (dye) dilution technique
  3. Thermodilution technique
  4. Ultrasonic Doppler transducer technique
  5. Doppler echocardiography
  6. Ballisto cardiography.

questions.text: A software engineer presents to the outpatient department with easy fatigability. He gives a history of sitting in front of the computer for 12 - 14 hours. He consumes a lot of junk food with very less fruits and vegetables. Hb is 9gm/dl and MCV 120 fl. What is the most likely cause of this patient's anemia? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Folic acid deficiency

 

The given laboratory values showing anemia and increased MC are suggestive of megaloblastic anemia.

 

This could be due to a lack of cyanocobalamin or folic acid. The lack of fruits and vegetables in the past suggests folic acid deficiency. (folic acid word derived from foliage-green leafy vegetables)

 

Animal products such as meat, fish, milk, and eggs are good sources of vitamin B12.

 

Green vegetables like lettuce, spinach, asparagus, and broccoli are high in folic acid.

 

In megaloblastic anemia, peripheral blood examination reveals oval macrocytes with anisocytosis and poikilocytosis. MCV is typically greater than 100 fL. (normal value: 80-100 fL). The MCHC is not elevated because most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and appear hyperchromic. The number of reticulocytes is low. Neutrophils are larger than normal and have five or more nuclear lobules, indicating nuclear hyper segmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyanocobalamin deficiency: Although vitamin B12 deficiency also causes megaloblastic anemia, the dietary history here suggests folic acid deficiency as the primary cause, given the lack of fruits and vegetables.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency anemia typically presents with microcytic (low MCV), hypochromic anemia, not macrocytic anemia as indicated by the elevated MCV.

 

Option D. Hereditary spherocytosis: This is a hemolytic anemia characterized by the presence of spherocytes (spherical red blood cells) and usually presents with a normal or slightly decreased MCV, not the significantly elevated MCV seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely cause of anemia in this patient, given the elevated MCV and dietary habits lacking in fruits and vegetables, is folic acid deficiency. Megaloblastic anemia due to folic acid deficiency presents with macrocytic red blood cells and can be confirmed by dietary history and characteristic blood smear findings.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of heavy alcohol use presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain that radiates to the back and recurrent vomiting. On examination, the patient has tenderness and guarding in the upper epigastrium. The chest x-ray is normal. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum Lipase

 

Serum lipase is an enzyme produced by the pancreas. Elevated levels of serum lipase are a hallmark of acute pancreatitis. It is a critical diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis in a patient with symptoms suggestive of pancreatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper GI endoscopy: Upper GI endoscopy is used to visualize the upper gastrointestinal tract, which may help diagnose conditions like peptic ulcers or esophagitis. However, in this case, the symptoms and clinical findings are more indicative of acute pancreatitis rather than upper GI issues.

 

Option B. Alcohol breath test: An alcohol breath test is used to detect recent alcohol consumption. While the patient has a history of heavy alcohol use, this test won't provide information about the current medical condition, such as pancreatitis.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): A contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT) can be a valuable tool for confirming the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis and assessing its severity. However, in many cases, a serum lipase test is ordered first because it's a quicker and less invasive way to diagnose acute pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abdominal pain with recurrent vomiting in a chronic alcoholic with upper epigastric guarding is highly suggestive of pancreatitis.
  • A normal erect chest x-ray suggests that there is no pneumoperitoneum, effectively ruling out perforation.
  • In this setting, the main differential diagnosis to consider is pancreatitis.
  • The next appropriate investigation would be a serum lipase test to confirm the diagnosis of pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old chef presented with complaints of leg pain and swelling. Upon examination, he was diagnosed with varicose veins. Further examination revealed the presence of skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis. According to the CEAP classification system, He would be classified as: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) C4

 

Explanation of the CEAP Classification:

 

The CEAP classification is a system used to categorize venous disease based on clinical, etiologic, anatomic, and pathophysiologic criteria. Here's a breakdown:

 

  • C: Clinical classification
  • E: Etiologic classification
  • A: Anatomic classification
  • P: Pathophysiologic classification

 

The "C" or clinical classification is divided as follows:

 

  • C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease.
  • C1: Telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • C2: Varicose veins.
  • C3: Edema.
  • C4: Skin changes without ulceration. This is further divided into:
    • C4a: Pigmentation or eczema.
    • C4b: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
    • C4c: Corona phlebectatica
  • C5: Skin changes with healed ulceration.
  • C6: Skin changes with active ulceration.

 

In summary, the patient's symptoms of varicose veins combined with skin changes such as eczema and lipodermatosclerosis correspond to the C4 classification in the CEAP system.

questions.text: A woman in her early 40s comes to your clinic, displaying a winding, pronounced swelling that covers the left region of her scalp and face, as visible in the provided image. Upon physical examination, you notice the swelling exhibits a rhythmic pulsation. When listening to the area with a stethoscope, a sound indicative of turbulent blood flow - a bruit - is heard. What could be the most probable diagnosis in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cirsoid Aneurysm

 

The above image is suggestive of a Cirsoid aneurysm.

 

  1. Definition: Cirsoid aneurysms, also known as arteriovenous fistulas or arteriovenous malformations, are abnormal connections between arteries and veins without the usual intervening capillaries.
  2. Common locations: They most commonly occur in the scalp and face, although they can occur in other locations in the body.
  3. Causes: They can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired, often as a result of trauma.
  4. Symptoms: Cirsoid aneurysms often present as a pulsatile mass, sometimes accompanied by a bruit (a sound heard over an artery due to turbulent blood flow). They can cause cosmetic concerns, headaches, and in severe cases, bleeding.
  5. Diagnosis: They can be diagnosed through physical examination and imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT, or MRI. Angiography can provide a detailed view of the blood vessels.
  6. Treatment: Treatment options include surgical excision, embolization (blocking off the abnormal vessels), or a combination of both. The choice of treatment depends on the size and location of the aneurysm, and the patient's overall health status.
  7. Complications: If left untreated, they can result in complications such as bleeding, ulceration, and, rarely, heart failure due to the increased blood flow through the malformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibromatosis:

 

  • Location: Neurofibromatosis (NF) is a genetic disorder that can affect multiple systems, including the skin and nerves.
  • Symptoms: Symptoms vary but can include skin tumors (neurofibromas), caf-au-lait spots, and neurological problems

 

 

Option B. Liposarcoma:

 

  • Location: Liposarcoma is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that typically arises in fat cells in various parts of the body, including the limbs and abdomen.
  • Causes: The exact cause is often unknown, but some genetic factors may contribute. Symptoms: Symptoms may include a painless lump, swelling, or pain in the affected area.

 

Option D. Varicocele:

 

  • Location: Varicoceles are dilated veins in the scrotum, specifically in the spermatic cord. Causes: Varicoceles often develop due to faulty valves in the testicular veins, which allow blood to pool in the scrotum.
  • Symptoms: They may cause a dull ache or discomfort in the scrotum, especially after prolonged standing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cirsoid aneurysms are arteriovenous malformations commonly found in the scalp and face, presenting as pulsatile masses with associated bruits. Proper diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications such as bleeding and cosmetic concerns.

choices.text: CCK - I cells, Duodenum and jejunum
Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

questions.text: Which of the subsequent pairs are inaccurately matched? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

 

Motilin is a gastrointestinal hormone produced by enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells (Not M cells) present in the stomach, small intestine, and colon.

M cells, or microfold cells, are specialized epithelial cells in the gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT) that play a crucial role in initiating mucosal immune responses, it does not release Motilin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrin - G cells, Antrum: Correct. Gastrin is produced by G cells located in the antrum of the stomach and stimulates H+ secretion by parietal cells.

 

Option B. Secretin - S cells, Duodenum: Correct. Secretin is produced by S cells in the duodenum and decreases gastric acid secretion while increasing pancreatic bicarbonate secretion.

 

Option C. CCK - I cells, Duodenum and jejunum: Correct. Cholecystokinin (CCK) is produced by I cells in the duodenum and jejunum, increasing pancreatic enzyme secretion and gallbladder contraction while decreasing gastric emptying and relaxing the sphincter of Oddi.

 

Option D. Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum: Incorrect. Motilin is produced by enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells in the stomach, small intestine, and colon, not exclusively by M cells in the duodenum and jejunum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GIT HORMONES

 

  • Gastrin G cell at antrum. Acts on Parietal cells stimulate the H+ K+ ATPase.
  • Secretin S cells at Duodenum. Decrease gastric acid secretion and Increase pancreatic HCO3- secretion.
  • CCK-PZ I cells in duodenum and jejunum. Increase pancreatic HCO3- secretion, Increase gall bladder contraction, Decrease gastric emptying and increase sphincter of Oddi relaxation.
  • GIP K cells in duodenum and jejunum. Decrease H+ secretion and increase insulin release.
  • Motilin Mo cells in small intestine. Produces migrating motor complexes (MMCs).

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to his left arm, which started 3 hours ago. He appears diaphoretic and anxious. His blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate is 95 beats per minute, and ECG shows nonspecific ST-segment changes. Given the timing of his symptoms, which biomarker would be the most appropriate investigation to diagnose myocardial infarction (MI) within 2-4 hours of symptom onset?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Myoglobin

 

Explanation:

 

Myoglobin is one of the earliest cardiac biomarkers to rise after myocardial injury, typically elevating within 1 to 4 hours of symptom onset. It peaks around 12 hours and normalizes within 24 hours. Due to its rapid rise, myoglobin is particularly useful in detecting myocardial infarction in the early hours when other biomarkers may still be within normal ranges. However, its lack of specificity to cardiac tissue means that while it is highly sensitive for early detection, it must be used in conjunction with other tests to confirm a diagnosis of MI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Troponin I (Tropl)
Troponin I starts to rise within 3 to 12 hours after myocardial infarction, making it less suitable for diagnosing MI within 2-4 hours of onset. Although Troponin I is highly specific for cardiac injury, its elevation time frame does not align with the immediate early phase of MI.

 

Option C. Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH)
LDH is a less specific marker of tissue injury and usually begins to rise 10 to 12 hours after myocardial infarction, peaking at 48 to 72 hours. It is not used for early diagnosis of MI due to its delayed rise and lack of specificity for cardiac muscle damage.

 

Option D. Troponin T (TropT)
Troponin T rises within 3 to 12 hours after myocardial infarction, peaking between 12 and 48 hours, and remains elevated for 7 to 10 days. It is highly specific for myocardial injury but is not an ideal early marker within the 2-4 hour window of symptom onset.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myoglobin is the earliest cardiac biomarker to rise following myocardial injury, usually within 1 to 4 hours, making it particularly useful for diagnosing myocardial infarction in the acute phase. Troponins, while highly specific and sensitive for cardiac injury, typically begin to rise later, around 3 to 12 hours after symptom onset. Understanding the time courses of various biomarkers is crucial in selecting the appropriate tests for early diagnosis of myocardial infarction.
